taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [No etymology stated in protologue; meaning uncertain]

bio:treatment.discussion: Deinandra is treated here as distinct from Hemizonia; Deinandra is more closely related to Calycadenia, Centromadia, Holocarpha, and Osmadenia than to Hemizonia in the strict sense (S. Carlquist et al. 2003). As circumscribed here (following B. G. Baldwin 1999b), Deinandra comprises all taxa included in Hemizonia sect. Madiomeris by B. D. Tanowitz (1982) plus the shrubs and subshrubs constituting the informal “Fruticosae” or “Zonamra” (J. Clausen 1951; D. D. Keck 1959b). All are self-incompatible except D. arida and D. mohavensis. Five species (D. frutescens, D. greeneana, D. martirensis, D. palmeri, D. streetsii), none annuals, are known only from Baja California, Mexico. Most species north of Mexico are cross-incompatible or ± intersterile (J. Clausen 1951).

references.reference: Tanowitz, B. D. 1982. Taxonomy of Hemizonia sect. Madiomeris (Asteraceae: Madiinae). Syst. Bot. 7: 314–339.

key_statement.description: Subshrubs or shrubs; paleae in 2 series or in 3+ series or throughout receptacles.
Paleae in 2 series (1 between ray and disc florets, 1 between outermost and adjacent discflorets); ray florets (11–)13(–20); anthers reddish to dark purple
Paleae in 3+ series or throughout receptacles; ray florets (4–)8; anthers yellow or brownish
Annuals; paleae in 1 series (between ray and disc florets).
Ray florets 3–5; disc florets 3–6; pappi of 5–12 scales.
Ray florets 3(–4); disc florets 3(–4)
Ray florets 5; disc florets 6.
Phyllaries usually sessile-glandular, at least near margins, rarely stipitate-glandular (stalks shorter than glands); anthers reddish to dark purple.
Bracts subtending heads usually overlapping at least proximal 1 / 2 of each involucre; phyllaries glandular near margins, sometimes with non-glandular, non-pustule-based hairs as well
Bracts subtending heads usually overlapping proximal 0– 1 / 2 of each involucre; phyllaries ± evenly glandular and with pustule-based hairs, atleast on midribs
Phyllaries stipitate-glandular (stalks often equal to or longer than glands); anthers yellow or brownish (reddish to dark purple or maroon in some, mostly s Californian, D . kelloggii ).
Proximal leaves usually pinnatifid to toothed (rarely entire); heads in open, paniculiform arrays; pappi of linear to oblong, entire or fringed scales
Proximal leaves usually entire, sometimes serrate; heads usually in glom-erules; pappi of irregular, erose scales
Ray florets (5–)8–35; disc florets 8–70; pappi 0, or of 1–14 scales, or coroniform (reputedly sometimes rudimentary).
Anthers yellow or brownish.
Faces of proximal leaves glabrous or hispid-hirsute and stipitate-glandular; disc florets 17–60; pappi usually 0, rarely of 1–5 linear to setiform scales 0.1–0.6 mm or, reputedly, rudimentary.
Stems solid; leaves (proximal) hispid-hirsute and stipitate-glandular; disc florets 17–25
Stems fistulose; leaves (proximal) glabrous (margins and midribs sometimes scabrous or hispid); disc florets 28–60
Faces of proximal leaves ± hirsute and stipitate-glandular; disc florets 10–21; pappi usually of 4–13 scales, sometimes coroniform (in D . bacigalupii ), rarely 0 (in Deinandra pallida ).
Ray laminae pale yellow, 6–12 mm
Ray laminae deep yellow, 2–4 mm
Anthers reddish to dark purple.
Disc florets all or mostly bisexual
Disc florets all or mostly functionally staminate.
Ray florets 15–35; pappi 0, or coroniform (irregular crowns of entire, erose, orlaciniate scales 0.1–0.9 mm)
Ray florets (7–)8–13; pappi of 4–14 elliptic, lanceolate, linear, oblong, or quadrate, barely fringed to erose scales 0.5–2 mm.
Phyllaries sessile- and stipitate-glandular, mostly near proximal margins and on apices
Phyllaries ± evenly stipitate-glandular, including margins and apices.
Ray florets (7–)8(–10); disc florets 8–14(–15) (basal leaves sometimes present at flowering in South Coast Ranges)
Ray florets 8–13(–15); disc florets 11–32
